posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
Hey all,

In the before times, I created a wrapper library to add WPILib simulation support to the REV library: Simulatable SparkMax

Well, seems official support for simulation still doesn’t exist, so I’ve updated my library for 2022!  There’s a few new changes, but they should line up with what REV changed, so I haven’t called them out explicitly in the project readme.

2022.1.1

Contribute to fletch3555/SparkMaxSim-java development by creating an account on GitHub.

Take a look and let me know if you have any issues or suggestions for improvement!

https://docs.revrobotics.com/sparkmax/software-resources/spark-max-api-information

It seems like there was some basic sim support in a 2022 update.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
You’re right, I just found it here: REVLib Information - SPARK MAX

I was going off of 2022.0.0 when I started looking, which didn’t have anything.  Guess I need to go take another look and see if there’s any gaps left for this library to fill.  If not, I guess I’ll be able to kill it off.

Thanks!

posts.name: Carl Hauser
posts.cooked: Has anyone found any documentation for the SPARK MAX simulation support beyond the few lines of code in the release info that show how to initialize the REVPhysicsSim and update it? Examples would be helpful as well. Specifically, I’m interested in drivetrain simulation, and I don’t see anything in REV’s simulation interfaces that would allow me to couple the drivebase characteristics (say, as obtained from sysid) to what REVPhysicsSim computes (presumably) for encoder values – or if it even does compute encoder values. I feel like I’m missing some key insight about what the SPARK MAX simulation is supposed to do, but nothing I’ve found provides what I think I need.

posts.name: Noah Andrews
posts.cooked: Our simulation support is pretty basic right now, and we’ll be expanding on it in the future. What the REVPhysicsSim takes care of is updating the reported position of the encoder, based on the velocities that the motor was commanded to run at. You can access that position by calling getPosition() on the SparkMaxRelativeEncoder object.

posts.name: Carl Hauser
posts.cooked: Thanks, Noah. I think I’ll continue using our own encoder simulations since we have those coupled to the drivebase physics.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: Noah, I assume this is all handled in the JNI layer? Just curious if the calculations were something I’d be able to access from my library.  I have most of it wrapped (and in some cases refactored based on personal preference) so that the simulation functionality is handled directly in the Java code, but it doesn’t do any real calculations.  Essentially, mine is a glorified logging tool for displaying values in the sim UI, and avoiding JNI calls (because 2020 that resulted in tons of errors in the console).

posts.name: Noah Andrews
posts.cooked:
The position calculations actually don’t use JNI at all. You can see how REVPhysicsSim works in the sources jar file. If you copy it and SparkMaxProfile to your library, they should work with minimal changes. They’ll just call getEncoder().getPosition() , getEncoder().getPositionConversionFactor() , and getEncoder().setPosition() .

By the way, calling JNI should work, as long as you’re using the original JNI classes in their original package. Can you see if you’re still having that issue?

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
The JNI issue was based on the 2020 library when I initially developed this, so it’s entirely possible it’s resolved now.  And for the record, it wasn’t JNI specifically, but the hardware/CAN communication that was failing (if I remember correctly at least).  I’ll definitely give it another try though.

Also, I don’t remember seeing those Sim classes, but I’ll take another look at that as well

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: I don’t recommend using this library right now.  As mentioned above, REV added some support for simulation (though I haven’t had a chance to confirm 100% feature parity with mine).

posts.name: Josie Bolotski
posts.cooked: I can’t seem to get NEO motor values to update in the SimGUI.  Below is simple test code in RobotContainer.java.  When I run the simulation and select Teleoperated mode, I expect the motor values in the SimGUI under Other Devices → SPARK MAX [1] to change, but they all stay at 0.  As a sanity check, the print statement at the end prints out “Motor speed: 0.5”.
